content.text: The **Copi system** (from Irving Copi's textbooks) is a popular natural deduction system with 18 rules: 9 rules of inference and 9 rules of replacement.

content.definition: One-way rules that take premises and produce conclusions: Modus Ponens, Modus Tollens, Hypothetical Syllogism, Disjunctive Syllogism, Constructive Dilemma, Simplification, Conjunction, Addition, Absorption.

content.title: Key Inference Rules
premises: HS: P → Q, Q → R ⊢ P → R
content.note: These rules only work in one direction — you apply them to derive new lines.

content.definition: Two-way equivalences: you can substitute equivalent forms anywhere. Includes De Morgan's, Double Negation, Commutativity, Associativity, Distribution, Material Implication, Exportation, Tautology.

content.title: Key Replacement Rules
content.note: These work both directions and can be applied to subformulas.

content.text: The Copi system doesn't use subproofs by default, though conditional proof and indirect proof can be added. It relies heavily on replacement rules to transform formulas.

content.question: What is the difference between rules of inference and rules of replacement?
options: Inference rules work one-way; replacement rules work both ways
content.explanation: Rules of inference (like MP) only work in one direction. Rules of replacement (like De Morgan's) are equivalences that work both ways and can be applied to subformulas.
